title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration, conservation, and easement expenses. The wetland restoration credit is based on expenditures for restoring farmed or converted wetlands to their natural state. The term 'wetland restoration expenditure' refers to expenses for restoring farmed or converted wetlands to their natural state within the first 5 years of a conservation agreement or easement. Expenditures must be approved by the Natural Resources Conservation Service and cannot include costs mandated by federal or state law. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and any compliance certification fees related to a qualified conservation agreement for the taxpayer's wetland. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and any compliance certification fees related to a qualified conservation agreement for the taxpayer's wetland. The applicable percentage varies based on the term of the conservation agreement, ranging from 50% to 70%. The wetland conservation credit is determined by the term of the conservation agreement, ranging from 50% to 70%. If a taxpayer elects the wetland easement credit, the conservation credit for that wetland is zero. The wetland easement credit is based on the fair market value of the wetland under a conservation easement. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement as a tax credit for the taxable year. The value is determined by a certified appraisal and the election applies to the specific year it is made. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement as a tax credit for the taxable year, determined by a certified appraisal. An election under this subsection applies to the specific year it is made. Definitions for eligible taxpayer and qualified wetland are provided for clarity. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement as a tax credit for the taxable year. A qualified wetland includes wetlands being converted to fully functioning condition through wetland restoration expenditures. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement as a tax credit. This includes wetlands being converted to fully functioning condition through restoration expenditures, as well as surrounding nonwetland areas for water quality or wildlife habitat buffering, with certain exclusions. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement as a tax credit, with certain exclusions related to nonwetland acreage and contract or easement payments received from specific programs. Wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland are defined by the Food Security Act of 1985. The Food Security Act of 1985 defines wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland. A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement with a governmental unit for 10-30 years to comply with conservation requirements. A qualified conservation agreement under section 170(c)(1) lasts 10-30 years, requires compliance with conservation requirements for the wetland, and certification of compliance every 5 years. Conservation requirements include not using the wetland for agricultural production. An eligible taxpayer complies with conservation requirements by not using the qualified wetland for agricultural production and refraining from any activities that alter the wetland's natural state. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by an eligible taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for conservation purposes. The taxpayer can restrict the use of a qualified wetland to a qualified organization for conservation purposes. Special rules include no double benefit and married couples must file joint returns. The taxpayer can restrict the use of a qualified wetland to a qualified organization for conservation purposes. Married couples must file joint returns for certain tax provisions. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments regarding wetland restoration and conservation expenses and overpayments of tax will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1998.
